elements.content: Three new cluster-based cobalt/carboxylate frameworks, formulated as {[H3O]­[CoII 7­(μ3-OH)3­(MeO-ip)6­(H2O)3]­·4.5H2O} n (1), {[CoII 6­(μ3-OH)2­(But-ip)4­(But-Hip)2­(H2O)2]­·2CH3CN} n (2), and {[CoII 5(Me-ip)4­(Me-Hip)2­(H2O)4]­·6H2O} n (3) (MeO-H2ip = 5-methoxyisophthalic acid, But-H2ip = 5-tert-buthylisophthalic acid, and Me-H2ip = 5-methylisophthalic acid) have been synthesized by the hydro(solvo)thermal reactions of Co2(CO)8 with the corresponding isophthalic acids in CH3CN, Pr i OH, and water. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that 1 and 2 both exhibit a three-dimensional (3D) pcu net based on hepta- and hexanuclear cobalt hydroxyl clusters {CoII 7(μ3-OH)3} and {CoII 6(μ3-OH)2}, respectively. Compound 3 is a 3D porous framework with an eight-connected bcu topology constructed from a pentanuclear cobalt cluster. It has been found that the structures of cobalt clusters in these compounds largely depend on the substituents on isophthalic acids. The magnetic studies indicate that both 1 and 2 show spin-canting antiferromagnetism, while 3 exhibits a magnetocaloric effect (MCE). The resulting entropy change of 3 is 13.23 J kg–1 K–1 for ΔH = 80 kG at 4 K.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that 1 and 2 both exhibit a three-dimensional (3D) pcu net based on hepta- and hexanuclear cobalt hydroxyl clusters {CoII 7(μ3-OH)3} and {CoII 6(μ3-OH)2}, respectively. The magnetic studies indicate that both 1 and 2 show spin-canting antiferromagnetism, while 3 exhibits a magnetocaloric effect (MCE). The resulting entropy change of 3 is 13.23 J kg-1 K-1 for ΔH = 80 kG at 4 K.

elements.content: Three new cobalt/isophthalate coordination polymers based on Co7, Co6, and Co5 clusters have been synthesized. The difference in electron-donating ability and steric hindrance of the substituents on the isophthalic acids is responsible for the diverse structures of Co clusters and network topologies of the resulting polymers. The Co7 and Co6 cluster-based polymers both show spin-canting antiferromagnetism, while the polymer with Co5 clusters displays a magnetocaloric effect.
elements.clean_text: Three new cobalt/isophthalate coordination polymers based on Co7, Co6, and Co5 clusters have been synthesized. The difference in electron-donating ability and steric hindrance of the substituents on the isophthalic acids is responsible for the diverse structures of Co clusters and network topologies of the resulting polymers. The Co7 and Co6 cluster-based polymers both show spin-canting antiferromagnetism, while the polymer with Co5 clusters displays a magnetocaloric effect.

elements.content: Coordination polymers (CPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention lately not only because of their interesting topologies but also because of their potential applications as functional materials in ions exchange, ferroelectric, catalysis, gas absorption, nonlinear optical devices, molecular magnetism, and so on. The key factors in the design and synthesis of MOFs with desirable properties and expected structures are mainly focused on the appropriate selection of nodes (metal ions or metal-including clusters) and spacers (organic or metallic ligands). More recently, the utilization of polymetallic clusters as secondary building blocks (SBUs) is of great interest in the construction of novel cluster-based MOFs with unique network topologies and interesting properties. In particular, the assembly of magnetic clusters with organic linkers opens up a new possibility to develop multifunctional materials such as porous magnets. For example, several cluster-based MOFs constructed by CoII-hydroxyl clusters with a nuclearity ranging from 3 to 8 and polycarboxylate linkers have been reported. However, as the generation of hydroxyl ions in this system is rather difficult to control and the existence of competitive coordination of carboxylate and hydroxyl groups to the metal centers in the assembly process, the synthesis of such cluster-based MOFs with the nuclearity of cobalt clusters greater than 5 is still a great challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable attention lately not only because of their interesting topologies but also because of their potential applications as functional materials in ions exchange, ferroelectric, catalysis, gas absorption, nonlinear optical devices, molecular magnetism, and so on. The key factors in the design and synthesis of MOFs with desirable properties and expected structures are mainly focused on the appropriate selection of nodes (metal ions or metal-including clusters) and spacers (organic or metallic ligands). More recently, the utilization of polymetallic clusters as secondary building blocks (SBUs) is of great interest in the construction of novel cluster-based MOFs with unique network topologies and interesting properties. In particular, the assembly of magnetic clusters with organic linkers opens up a new possibility to develop multifunctional materials such as porous magnets. For example, several cluster-based MOFs constructed by CoII-hydroxyl clusters with a nuclearity ranging from 3 to 8 and polycarboxylate linkers have been reported. However, as the generation of hydroxyl ions in this system is rather difficult to control and the existence of competitive coordination of carboxylate and hydroxyl groups to the metal centers in the assembly process, the synthesis of such cluster-based MOFs with the nuclearity of cobalt clusters greater than 5 is still a great challenge.

elements.content: On the other hand, molecular-based magnetic materials having a cryogenic magnetocaloric effect (MCE) are of great interest due to their potential application as a magnetic refrigerant material. MCE is a magnetothermodynamic phenomenon characterized by the entropy change (ΔS M) in an isothermal process and by the temperature change (ΔT ad) in an adiabatic process as a result of a magnetic field variation. Nevertheless, most of the studies are focused on discrete clusters, and the MCE exploration of 3D MOFs based on multinuclear cluster nodes is extremely sparse. Therefore, it will be interesting and worthy to explore MCE in cluster-based MOFs. Moreover, it is well-known that the design and synthesis of cluster-based MOFs are influenced by many factors, such as pH values, solvents, reaction temperature, templates, and the nature of the organic ligands. Among these factors, the shape and electronic property of a ligand play an important role in the structure of final products. In fact, a small modification of one ligand may sometimes be sufficient to bring about changes in product structures. Therefore, MOFs structure can be effectively tuned through slight variation of a ligand. In comparison to common carboxylic ligands such as 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, R-isophthalic acids remain largely unexplored despite their potential to form unexpected and interesting structures with metal ions as the R substituents having different electron donating capabilities and steric hindrance may affect the coordination abilities and modes of related carboxylic groups. With this in mind, we employed MeO-H2ip (5-methoxyisophthalic acid), But-H2ip (5-tert-butylisophthalic acid), and Me-H2ip (5-methylisophthalic acid) to assemble with CoII ion under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions, affording three new cluster-based cobalt/carboxylate MOFs, namely, {[H3O][CoII 7(μ3-OH)3­(MeO-ip)6­(H2O)3]­·4.5H2O} n (1), {[CoII 6(μ3-OH)2­(Bu t -ip)4­(Bu t -Hip)2­(H2O)2]­·2CH3CN} n (2), and {[CoII 5(Me-ip)4­(Me-Hip)2­(H2O)4]­·6H2O} n (3). Interestingly, compounds 1–3 are built upon cobalt clusters with different nuclearity and structures, which could be ascribed to their different substituted groups at 5-position on the isophthalic acids. In this paper, we describe the synthesis, structures, and magnetic properties of these compounds.

elements.content: All the materials were purchased from the commercial sources and used without further purification. Thermogravimetric experiments were performed using a TGA/NETZSCH STA449C instrument heated from 30–800 °C (heating rate of 10 °C/min, nitrogen stream). Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. High-resolution PXRD patterns were collected using PANalytical X’Pert Pro (Cu Kα radiation: λ = 1.54056 Å) in the range of 5° < 2θ < 65°. IR spectra were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One using KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1 (Figure S1 in the ). Magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples with a Quantum Design PPMS-9T system. Diamagnetic corrections were made using Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the materials were purchased from the commercial sources and used without further purification. Thermogravimetric experiments were performed using a TGA/NETZSCH STA449C instrument heated from 30-800 °C (heating rate of 10 °C/min, nitrogen stream). Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. High-resolution PXRD patterns were collected using PANalytical X'Pert Pro (Cu Kα radiation: λ = 1.54056 Å) in the range of 5° < 2θ < 65°. IR spectra were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One using KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 (Figure S1 in the ). Magnetic susceptibilities were measured on polycrystalline samples with a Quantum Design PPMS-9T system. Diamagnetic corrections were made using Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku diffractometer equipped with a Mercury CCD area detector (Mo Kα; λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. CrystalClear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXTL and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELX-97 program. Metal atoms in each compound were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, except C35, C36, and C37 atoms in 2. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were generated geometrically (C–H 0.97 or 0.93 Å) and U(H) values set as 1.2 times Ueq(C). In 1, the atom C4, C5, C6, C7, C19, and O11 are disordered with two positions and are refined as two atoms with the occupancy of 0.5, viz. C4 and C4A, C5 and C5A, C6 and C6A, C7 and C7A, C19 and C19A, O11 and O11A, respectively. Since the position of the disorder water molecules and H3O+ cations could not be resolved from Fourier maps, PLATON/SQUEEZE was used to compensate the data for their contribution to the diffraction patterns for 1 and 3. The final chemical formula of 1 and 3 were calculated from SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA and elemental analysis data. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information for these compounds are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) for 1, 2, and 3 are listed in Tables S1–S3 in the . CCDC numbers for compounds 1–3 are 939667–939669, respectively.

Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku diffractometer equipped with a Mercury CCD area detector (Mo Kα; λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. CrystalClear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXTL and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using SHELX-97 program. Metal atoms in each compound were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, except C35, C36, and C37 atoms in 2. The hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon were generated geometrically (C-H 0.97 or 0.93 Å) and U(H) values set as 1.2 times Ueq(C). In 1, the atom C4, C5, C6, C7, C19, and O11 are disordered with two positions and are refined as two atoms with the occupancy of 0.5, viz. C4 and C4A, C5 and C5A, C6 and C6A, C7 and C7A, C19 and C19A, O11 and O11A, respectively. Since the position of the disorder water molecules and H3O+ cations could not be resolved from Fourier maps, PLATON/SQUEEZE was used to compensate the data for their contribution to the diffraction patterns for 1 and 3. The final chemical formula of 1 and 3 were calculated from SQUEEZE results combined with the TGA and elemental analysis data. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information for these compounds are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) for 1, 2, and 3 are listed in Tables S1-S3 in the . CCDC numbers for compounds 1-3 are 939667-939669, respectively.

Hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis has been proven to be a convenient and powerful synthetic technique for the preparation of metal–organic frameworks. In general, assembly of CoII/isophthalate frameworks under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions is really difficult without the help of N-containing auxiliary ligands, typically dipyridyl derivatives. The CoII center in the resulting products is thus coordinated with both isophthalate groups and pyridyl ligands. In the case of R-isophthalic acids (R = MeO, Bu t , and Me), only three frameworks based solely on the carboxylate ligand have been observed so far. It seems that although the auxiliary dipyridyl ligands are very important in the construction of these frameworks, they disfavor the formation of polynuclear Co clusters. For example, most of the compounds prepared with the assistance of a mixed ligand system of R-isophthalic acids and dipyridyl-based ligands contain either single CoII ions or dinuclear CoII units as connecting nodes, and there are only two examples, {[Co3(OH)­(Bu t -ip)2­(Bu t -Hip)­(bpp)]} n and {[Co8(OH)4­(Bu t -ip)6­(H2O)9]­·12H2O}, which have a trinuclear cluster node [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ and a heptanuclear node [Co7(μ3-OH)4]10+, respectively. We found that by using zerovalent cobalt compounds as precursors, cluster-based CoII/carboxylate coordination polymers could be obtained without any auxiliary N-containing ligands. Thus, compounds 1–3 were obtained in moderate yields by treatment of Co2(CO)8 and R-isophthalic acids (R = MeO, Bu t , and Me) with a molar ratio of 1:4 in a mixed-solvent of CH3CN, Pr i OH, and H2O (v/v/v = 3:3:1) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions (Scheme ). Under similar conditions, no products could be obtained by using various CoII salts instead of Co2(CO)8. Because of the complexity involved in the hydro(solvo)thermal reaction at high temperature and pressure conditions, so far we are unable to explain why the synthesis of 1–3 works only with Co2(CO)8. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been used to check the phase purity of the bulk samples in the solid state. The measured PXRD patterns of 1–3 are in good agreement with the simulated patterns generated from the results of single-crystal diffraction data (Figure S2 in the ), indicating that the as-synthesized samples are pure.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Compounds 1-3 

Hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis has been proven to be a convenient and powerful synthetic technique for the preparation of metal-organic frameworks. In general, assembly of CoII/isophthalate frameworks under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions is really difficult without the help of N-containing auxiliary ligands, typically dipyridyl derivatives. The CoII center in the resulting products is thus coordinated with both isophthalate groups and pyridyl ligands. In the case of R-isophthalic acids (R = MeO, Bu t , and Me), only three frameworks based solely on the carboxylate ligand have been observed so far. It seems that although the auxiliary dipyridyl ligands are very important in the construction of these frameworks, they disfavor the formation of polynuclear Co clusters. For example, most of the compounds prepared with the assistance of a mixed ligand system of R-isophthalic acids and dipyridyl-based ligands contain either single CoII ions or dinuclear CoII units as connecting nodes, and there are only two examples, {[Co3(OH)(Bu t -ip)2(Bu t -Hip)(bpp)]} n   and {[Co8(OH)4(Bu t -ip)6(H2O)9]⋅12H2O}, which have a trinuclear cluster node [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ and a heptanuclear node [Co7(μ3-OH)4]10+, respectively. We found that by using zerovalent cobalt compounds as precursors, cluster-based CoII/carboxylate coordination polymers could be obtained without any auxiliary N-containing ligands. Thus, compounds 1-3 were obtained in moderate yields by treatment of Co2(CO)8 and R-isophthalic acids (R = MeO, Bu t , and Me) with a molar ratio of 1:4 in a mixed-solvent of CH3CN, Pr i OH, and H2O (v/v/v = 3:3:1) under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions (Scheme ). Under similar conditions, no products could be obtained by using various CoII salts instead of Co2(CO)8. Because of the complexity involved in the hydro(solvo)thermal reaction at high temperature and pressure conditions, so far we are unable to explain why the synthesis of 1-3 works only with Co2(CO)8. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) has been used to check the phase purity of the bulk samples in the solid state. The measured PXRD patterns of 1-3 are in good agreement with the simulated patterns generated from the results of single-crystal diffraction data (Figure S2 in the ), indicating that the as-synthesized samples are pure.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of Compounds 1-3

elements.content: X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the space group R3̅c with a heptanuclear cobalt hydroxyl cluster {CoII 7(μ3-OH)3} as the secondary building unit (SBU, Figure a). The Co7 cluster is composed of three {Co3O} triangles sharing a common divalent cobalt ion and can be viewed as a “windmill”. Its asymmetric unit consists of three crystallographically independent octahedral CoII ions: Co1 and Co2 are in a general position, whereas Co3 lies along a 3-fold axis with a site multiplicity of 1/3 (Figure S3a in the ). The three Co atoms form an unequilateral triangle with the Co···Co distances of 3.090(1), 3.361(9), and 3.644(2) Ǻ and the Co···Co···Co angles of 59.21(7), 52.15(3), and 68.63(1)°, respectively. The three Co atoms are all octahedrally coordinated but in different coordination environments: Co1 is surrounded by a μ3-OH group and five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1A, O2A, O4B, and O7). Co2 is coordinated to four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O3B, O5C, O6D, and O8), one μ3-bridging hydroxyl group (O9), and one coordinated water molecule (O10). Co3 is ligated by three bridging μ3-OH groups (O9, O9A, and O9E) and three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O6C, O6D, and O6F). The Co–O bond lengths (2.027(2)–2.511(3) Ǻ) are in the range commonly observed for the CoII compounds, suggesting that all the Co ions are in the oxidation state of +2. The assignment of the oxidation state of CoII ions in 1 is further supported by the BVS calculations for Co1, Co2, and Co3, which gave oxidation state values of 1.90, 2.020, and 2.077, respectively (see for calculation detail). In 1, three {Co3O} triangles form a trigonal-prismatic heptanuclear cobalt cluster structurally similar to that found in [KCo7­(OH)3­(ip)6­(H2O)4]­·12H2O. As shown in , each Co7 cluster is linked to three neighboring ones by three pairs of MeO-ip2– ligands with a (k 1-k 1)-(k 1-μ2)-μ5 bridging mode (Scheme a) and to the other three neighboring ones through three pairs of MeO-ip2– ligands with a (k 1-k 1)-(k 2-μ2)-μ4 bridging mode (Scheme b), generating a 3D network (Figure b). The solvent-accessible void volume calculated by PLATON is about 15.2% after removal of the lattice water molecules. If the MeO-ip2– anion can be viewed as a connector and the Co7 cluster as a node, the 3D framework of 1 can be abstracted into a six-connected pcu net with the Schläfli symbol of 41263 (Figure c). It should be noted that one-third positive charge per asymmetric unit is necessary to neutralize the negative charge. Unfortunately, no cation could be located from the difference Fourier maps. Except the central CoII ion, only the coordinated water molecule resides on the 3-fold rotation axis. Thus, we can speculate that the coordination water molecule bears a proton to form a hydronium ion. A similar situation has been observed elsewhere for compounds such as [(H3O)2Co3­[Re6Se8(CN)6]2­·4.5H2O].

X-ray analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in the space group R3̅c with a heptanuclear cobalt hydroxyl cluster {CoII 7(μ3-OH)3} as the secondary building unit (SBU, Figure a). The Co7 cluster is composed of three {Co3O} triangles sharing a common divalent cobalt ion and can be viewed as a "windmill". Its asymmetric unit consists of three crystallographically independent octahedral CoII ions: Co1 and Co2 are in a general position, whereas Co3 lies along a 3-fold axis with a site multiplicity of 1/3 (Figure S3a in the ). The three Co atoms form an unequilateral triangle with the Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances of 3.090(1), 3.361(9), and 3.644(2) Ǻ and the Co⋅⋅⋅Co⋅⋅⋅Co angles of 59.21(7), 52.15(3), and 68.63(1)°, respectively. The three Co atoms are all octahedrally coordinated but in different coordination environments: Co1 is surrounded by a μ3-OH group and five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1A, O2A, O4B, and O7). Co2 is coordinated to four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O3B, O5C, O6D, and O8), one μ3-bridging hydroxyl group (O9), and one coordinated water molecule (O10). Co3 is ligated by three bridging μ3-OH groups (O9, O9A, and O9E) and three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O6C, O6D, and O6F). The Co-O bond lengths (2.027(2)-2.511(3) Ǻ) are in the range commonly observed for the CoII compounds, suggesting that all the Co ions are in the oxidation state of +2. The assignment of the oxidation state of CoII ions in 1 is further supported by the BVS calculations for Co1, Co2, and Co3, which gave oxidation state values of 1.90, 2.020, and 2.077, respectively (see  for calculation detail). Except the central CoII ion, only the coordinated water molecule resides on the 3-fold rotation axis. Thus, we can speculate that the coordination water molecule bears a proton to form a hydronium ion. A similar situation has been observed elsewhere for compounds such as [(H3O)2Co3[Re6Se8(CN)6]2⋅4.5H2O].

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the space group P1̅. The asymmetric unit contains three crystallographic independent CoII ions, one Bu t -Hip– monoanion, one OH– anion, two Bu t -ip 2– dianion, one coordinated H2O molecule as well as one guest CH3CN molecule (Figure S4a in the ). The three Co atoms display two different coordination geometries. As shown in Figure a, Co1 and Co2 atoms are in an octahedral geometry but in different coordination environments: Co1 is coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O1C, O5, O3B, and O11A) and one μ3-bridging hydroxyl group (O13), while Co2 is surrounded by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O6C, O8D, and O9), one μ3-bridging hydroxyl group (O13), and one coordinated water molecule (O14). Co3 atom adopts a tetrahedral coordination geometry and is bound to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4B, O7D, and O12A) and one μ3-bridging hydroxyl group (O13). The three crystallographic independent CoII ions are connected by carboxylate groups and a μ3-OH oxygen to yield a {Co3(μ3-OH)} cluster. Two such Co3 clusters are linked together by carboxylate groups to form a {Co6(μ3-OH)2} building block. The BVS calculations based on the Co–O interatomic distances for Co1 (2.084), Co2 (1.945), and Co3 (1.852) agreed well with the +2 valence state (). As shown in , each {Co6(μ3-OH)2} cluster is connected to six nearest neighbors along a, b, and c directions with two pairs of ligands adopting a (k 1-k 1)-(k 1-μ2)-μ5, a (k 1-k 1)-(k 1-k 1)-μ4, and a k 1-(k 1-k 1)-μ3 coordination mode, respectively (Scheme a,d,f). Three such coordination modes envelop the {Co6(μ3-OH)2} clusters and connect them into a 3D framework with the intercluster separations of 11.08–14.52 Ǻ (center to center) (Figure b). Although the Bu t -ip2– ligands with 2a and 2d coordination modes are observed in MOFs, no example of the Bu t -Hip – ligand with a 2f coordination mode has been reported. From the topological point of view, each Co6 subunit can be viewed as a node, which is connected to its six neighboring ones by carboxylate groups to generate a 3D pcu topologic network (Figure c).

elements.content: The crystallographic asymmetric unit of 3 contains five CoII ions, four Me-ip2– dianions, two Me-Hip– monoanions, and four coordinated water molecules (Figure S5a in the ). In the asymmetric unit of 3, the Co1, Co2, and Co3 atoms are in a linear structure, in which each Co atom is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral geometry. As shown in Figure a, the terminal Co1 and Co3 atoms are each coordinated by five oxygen atoms from four different carboxylate groups and one water molecule, while the center Co2 atom is surrounded by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different carboxylate groups. Both Co4 and Co5 are four-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms and one water molecule to complete a tetrahedral geometry. BVS calculations for the five Co ions (1.762–1.949) indicate that they are all in an oxidation state of +2 (). In the linear Co3 cluster, the center Co2 atom is connected to Co1 and Co3 atoms by two pairs of syn–syn carboxylate bridges and two μ2-O bridges (O7 and O1B). The terminal Co1 and Co3 atoms are each attached to other Co atoms (Co4 and Co5) via a syn–anti carboxylate bridge to form a Co5 cluster building block. These basic building blocks are expanded to a complicated 3D network with the aid of 12 carboxylate ligands (Figure b), in which eight of them exhibit 2c and 2e coordination modes, respectively, while the four others adopt a 2g coordination mode (Scheme and ). To fully understand the network structure of 3, a topological approach is applied to simplify such a 3D coordination framework. Taking the carboxylate ligands as connectors and the Co5 blocks as nodes, an eight-connected bcu topology with the Schläfli symbol of 42464 can be abstracted (Figure c). When viewed from the a-axis, a 1D channel (7.8 × 8.0 Å2) exists occupied by water molecules (Figure S6 in the ). Upon removal of the water molecules, the solvent-accessible void volume is about 18.1% as estimated by PLATON.

elements.content: It is worthy to note that in spite of the same synthetic conditions employed, compounds 1–3 exhibit 3D structures with different SBUs and the numbers of coordinated hydroxyl groups. This indicates that the substituents on isophthalic acids have a remarkable effect on the structures of the resulting compounds. First, the ligands in 1–3 adopt diverse coordination modes to connect CoII ions, giving rise to Co clusters with different nuclearities. For example, the 12 carboxylate groups in 1 are all deprotonated and adopt three different coordination modes, six of which are bridging bidentate, four carboxylate groups are bridging-chelate tridentate and the other two are bridging tridentate, which result in the formation of a Co7 cluster. In the Co6 cluster of 2, except one carboxylate group that adopts a bridging tridentate mode, the other nine carboxylate groups are involved in a bridging bidentate mode. Besides, there are two carboxyl groups that are in a monodentate mode. In the Co5 cluster of 3, two monodentate carboxyl groups exist, as well as two monodentate, two bridging-chelate tridentate, and six bridging bidentate carboxylate groups. Second, the SUBs of compounds 1–3 contain different numbers of coordinated hydroxyl groups: three for Co7, two for Co6, and zero for Co5. Third, compounds 1–3 display different topologies: 1 and 2 show a six-connected pcu topology, whereas 3 exhibits an eight-connected bcu topology. Since the carboxylic coordination sites of the three ligands are similar, it can be safely assumed that the main cause for such structural differences would stem from the different electron-donating ability and steric hindrance of the substituents on the isophthalic acids.

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability of compounds 1, 2, and 3, thermal analyses have been carried out on crystalline sample in a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure S7 in the ). The TGA curve of 1 indicates that there is a weight loss of 8.82% from 40 to 230 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of five and half lattice H2O molecules and three coordinated H2O molecules (calcd = 8.61%). Then no marked weight loss was observed until 400 °C, from which the framework begins to decompose. The curve of 2 shows that two free CH3CN molecules and two coordinated H2O molecules are lost in the region 40–350 °C with a loss of 6.91% (calcd = 6.46%), and above 350 °C the framework of 2 is gradually collapsed. For 3, the TGA curve shows no noticeable platform, indicating that the lattice and coordinated H2O molecules in the framework are gradually lost. When the temperature reaches to 180 °C, all the H2O molecules (calcd = 9.49%) are lost (observed = 9.76%). After that temperature, the framework of 3 decomposes owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Characterization

To investigate the thermal stability of compounds 1, 2, and 3, thermal analyses have been carried out on crystalline sample in a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (Figure S7 in the ). The TGA curve of 1 indicates that there is a weight loss of 8.82% from 40 to 230 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of five and half lattice H2O molecules and three coordinated H2O molecules (calcd = 8.61%). Then no marked weight loss was observed until 400 °C, from which the framework begins to decompose. The curve of 2 shows that two free CH3CN molecules and two coordinated H2O molecules are lost in the region 40-350 °C with a loss of 6.91% (calcd = 6.46%), and above 350 °C the framework of 2 is gradually collapsed. For 3, the TGA curve shows no noticeable platform, indicating that the lattice and coordinated H2O molecules in the framework are gradually lost. When the temperature reaches to 180 °C, all the H2O molecules (calcd = 9.49%) are lost (observed = 9.76%). After that temperature, the framework of 3 decomposes owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands.

elements.content: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data of polycrystalline 1, 2, and 3 are measured under a field of 1 kOe in the temperature range of 2–300 K. Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit very similar magnetic behavior, and only the magnetic properties of 1 are discussed here. The temperature dependence of x m T product per CoII 7 unit is shown in Figure . At 300 K, the x m T value is 20.95 cm3 mol–1 K, much higher than the expected spin-only value of 13.13 cm3 mol–1 K for CoII 7 (CoII, S = 3/2 and g = 2.0), which indicates a significant orbital contribution of octahedral CoII ions. Upon cooling, the x m T decreases continuously and reaches a minimum of 8.67 cm3 mol–1 K at 34 K and then abruptly increases to a peak of 9.67 cm3 mol–1 K at 30 K, followed by a drop down to 2.09 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. In the higher temperature range, the reciprocal molar magnetic susceptibility data obeys Curie–Weiss law with the Weiss constant θ = −103.84 K (Figure S8a in the ). The large negative θ and the high temperature behavior of x m T indicate that the dominant interactions between CoII ions is antiferromagnetic, although spin–orbital coupling and zero-splitting may also contribute to this large θ value. The abrupt increase of x m T below 34 K suggests the occurrence of weak ferromagnetism, which may arise from the presence of spin-canting. In a spin-canting system, the predominantly antiferromagnetic coupling spins from different sublattices are not perfectly antiparallel, but canted to each other, and the resulting net moments are correlated in a ferromagnetic-like fashion. The magnetization curve (M–H) is shown in Figure . At 2 K, the magnetization increases rapidly at low-field region, whereas it increases linearly in a high-field region, and reaches the maximum value of 6.59 NμB at 8 T, which is far from the saturated value of 15.17 NμB (assuming S′ = 1/2 and g oct = 13/3). A very small hysteresis loop was observed (inset of Figure ) with the coercive field of 80 Oe and a weak remnant magnetization of 0.021 NμB, suggesting the spin-canting behavior. Besides, the magnetization M versus H/T plots show a large deviation from scaling, which indicates significant anisotropy in the compound and/or the presence of low-lying excited levels (inset of Figure ). In order to further investigate the low-temperature magnetic properties of 1, the AC susceptibility was further performed under the DC field H DC = 0 Oe and the AC field H AC = 3 Oe from 2 to 40 K (Figure S9 in the ). No in-phase and out-of-phase peaks were observed in the temperature range of 2–40 K. Generally, the spin-canting can arise from two contributions: (1) the presence of the antisymmetric exchange and (2) the single-ion magnetic anisotropy. Because of the existence of inversion center in the Co7 cluster, the spin-canting behavior in 1 may be caused by the anisotropy of the CoII ions.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of 3 is different from that of 1 and 2. As shown in Figure , the value of x m T slowly decreases from 14.16 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K to 13.31 cm3 mol–1 K at 100 K and then rapidly decreases reaching a value of 9.15 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. As observed in 1, the value of x m T (14.16 cm3 mol–1 K) at room temperature is larger than the expected value for five uncoupled CoII ions (9.38 cm3 mol–1 K), which also resulted from the orbital contribution of octahedral CoII ions. The Curie–Weiss fit in the whole temperature range gives a very small negative Weiss constant θ = −5.94 K (Figure S11 in the ), indicating the very weak antiferromagnetic coupling between CoII centers. This very small negative Weiss constant urges us to investigate the magnetocaloric effect (MCE) of 3. The field dependence of magnetization curves were measured up to 80 KG in the temperature range of 2–7 K (Figure , inset). The magnetic entropy changes ΔS M were calculated from these magnetization data using Maxwell equation ΔS m = ∫[∂M(T,H)/∂T] H dH (Figure ). It can be seen that the maximum value of −ΔS m is 13.23 J kg–1 K–1 for ΔH = 80 kG at 4 K, which is lower than the expected value of 26.01 J kg–1 K–1 according to the equation nR ln(2S + 1) for five isolated CoII ions. The observed maximum value of −ΔS m is larger than that for some Mn or Fe clusters, but smaller than that observed for most of the molecule-based magnetic cryocooling materials which is in the range of 14.6–50.1 J kg–1 K–1. To the best of our knowledge, the MCE investigation on metal–organic frameworks, especially those based on high-nuclear metal clusters, is extremely rare In fact, the only one example reported is {[Gd5Zn(BPDC)3­(H2O)10­(μ3-OH)6]­·(CO3)0.5­·(NO3)4­·12H2O} n (BPDC = 4,4′-dicarboxylate-2,2′-dipyridine anion), which has been found to have a large MCE up to 30.7 J kg–1 K–1. Thus, compound 3 is the first example of transition metal cluster-based MOFs whose magnetocaloric effect is investigated.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized three new 3D CoII/carboxylate coordination polymers with different cobalt cluster SBUs by changing the substituents at the 5-position of isophthalic acids under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. We found that the substituents greatly influenced the coordination modes of the R-isophthalic acids with CoII ions, resulting in a structural difference in the SBUs of the frameworks. In the case when R is MeO, the resulting product 1 is a 3D MOF with a Co7 SBU. By using Bu t - and Me-isophthalic acids, MOFs 2 and 3 with Co6 and Co5 SBUs, respectively, are obtained. The magnetic studies indicate that 1 and 2 both show spin-canting antiferromagnetism, while 3 displays an MCE with an entropy change of 13.23 J kg–1 K–1 for ΔH = 80 kG at 4 K, which is the first investigation of MCE on the 3D MOFs based on Co cluster nodes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized three new 3D CoII/carboxylate coordination polymers with different cobalt cluster SBUs by changing the substituents at the 5-position of isophthalic acids under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. We found that the substituents greatly influenced the coordination modes of the R-isophthalic acids with CoII ions, resulting in a structural difference in the SBUs of the frameworks. In the case when R is MeO, the resulting product 1 is a 3D MOF with a Co7 SBU. By using Bu t - and Me-isophthalic acids, MOFs 2 and 3 with Co6 and Co5 SBUs, respectively, are obtained. The magnetic studies indicate that 1 and 2 both show spin-canting antiferromagnetism, while 3 displays an MCE with an entropy change of 13.23 J kg-1 K-1 for ΔH = 80 kG at 4 K, which is the first investigation of MCE on the 3D MOFs based on Co cluster nodes.

cln_elements.content:
To investigate the thermal stability of compounds 1, 2, and 3, thermal analyses have been carried out on crystalline sample in a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure S7 in the ). The TGA curve of 1 indicates that there is a weight loss of 8.82% from 40 to 230 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of five and half lattice H2O molecules and three coordinated H2O molecules (calcd = 8.61%). Then no marked weight loss was observed until 400 °C, from which the framework begins to decompose. The curve of 2 shows that two free CH3CN molecules and two coordinated H2O molecules are lost in the region 40–350 °C with a loss of 6.91% (calcd = 6.46%), and above 350 °C the framework of 2 is gradually collapsed. For 3, the TGA curve shows no noticeable platform, indicating that the lattice and coordinated H2O molecules in the framework are gradually lost. When the temperature reaches to 180 °C, all the H2O molecules (calcd = 9.49%) are lost (observed = 9.76%). After that temperature, the framework of 3 decomposes owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands.

Magnetic Properties

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data of polycrystalline 1, 2, and 3 are measured under a field of 1 kOe in the temperature range of 2–300 K. Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit very similar magnetic behavior, and only the magnetic properties of 1 are discussed here. The temperature dependence of x m T product per CoII 7 unit is shown in Figure . At 300 K, the x m T value is 20.95 cm3 mol–1 K, much higher than the expected spin-only value of 13.13 cm3 mol–1 K for CoII 7 (CoII, S = 3/2 and g = 2.0), which indicates a significant orbital contribution of octahedral CoII ions. Upon cooling, the x m T decreases continuously and reaches a minimum of 8.67 cm3 mol–1 K at 34 K and then abruptly increases to a peak of 9.67 cm3 mol–1 K at 30 K, followed by a drop down to 2.09 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. In the higher temperature range, the reciprocal molar magnetic susceptibility data obeys Curie–Weiss law with the Weiss constant θ = −103.84 K (Figure S8a in the ). The large negative θ and the high temperature behavior of x m T indicate that the dominant interactions between CoII ions is antiferromagnetic, although spin–orbital coupling and zero-splitting may also contribute to this large θ value. The abrupt increase of x m T below 34 K suggests the occurrence of weak ferromagnetism, which may arise from the presence of spin-canting. In a spin-canting system, the predominantly antiferromagnetic coupling spins from different sublattices are not perfectly antiparallel, but canted to each other, and the resulting net moments are correlated in a ferromagnetic-like fashion. The magnetization curve (M–H) is shown in Figure . At 2 K, the magnetization increases rapidly at low-field region, whereas it increases linearly in a high-field region, and reaches the maximum value of 6.59 NμB at 8 T, which is far from the saturated value of 15.17 NμB (assuming S′ = 1/2 and g oct = 13/3). A very small hysteresis loop was observed (inset of Figure ) with the coercive field of 80 Oe and a weak remnant magnetization of 0.021 NμB, suggesting the spin-canting behavior. Besides, the magnetization M versus H/T plots show a large deviation from scaling, which indicates significant anisotropy in the compound and/or the presence of low-lying excited levels (inset of Figure ). In order to further investigate the low-temperature magnetic properties of 1, the AC susceptibility was further performed under the DC field H DC = 0 Oe and the AC field H AC = 3 Oe from 2 to 40 K (Figure S9 in the ). No in-phase and out-of-phase peaks were observed in the temperature range of 2–40 K. Generally, the spin-canting can arise from two contributions: (1) the presence of the antisymmetric exchange and (2) the single-ion magnetic anisotropy. Because of the existence of inversion center in the Co7 cluster, the spin-canting behavior in 1 may be caused by the anisotropy of the CoII ions.
